data.title: Nu Holdings: Global Expansion And Local Politics Fuel Bullish Outlook For 2026
data.description:
Editor's note: Seeking Alpha is proud to welcome Daniel Herkenhoff as a new contributing analyst. You can become one too! Share your best investment idea by submitting your article for review to our editors. Get published, earn money, and unlock exclusive SA Premium access. Click here to find out more »

Why NU Deserves Your Attention

Nu Holdings (NU) is, by management's own words, the "largest and most loved digital retail bank" on earth. Currently with 131 million customers, its scalable, low-cost operations help deliver impressive profitability growth. This year could be an inflection point for NU's global expansion, recent wins of banking licenses, and local politics that could prove to be a considerable tailwind of revenue. I currently have a Buy rating on NU. Below are my key reasons.

My Take on the Business

Being from Brazil, I first heard of Nubank a few years ago by word of mouth, well before the bank started its massive marketing campaigns across the country. What caught my attention at first was how easy and fast it was to open an account and also how seamless the integration between checking and savings accounts looked, with a well-developed app.

Brazil is still a country with a largely unbanked population, especially lower-income individuals. Cristina Junqueira and David Vélez saw this open sea of opportunities and built something simple but powerful: a fully digital bank (checking, loans, investments, insurance, even crypto) that's super user-friendly. That yielded the bank 113 million customers in Brazil, its main market, and it became the largest private financial institution by number of clients, according to the Brazilian Central Bank. That's 62% of the total adult population (up from only 10% in 2019) while maintaining above 86% of its base as active users. Simply insane engagement.

And now, with Brazil approaching saturation in the mass market, the next chapter is international. NU is already winning in Mexico and Colombia. And the U.S. is next. The model that transformed Brazilian finance has huge potential to do the same globally. As someone who's used it from the early days, I see why the momentum feels unstoppable.

FY 2025 Numbers and Momentum

NU just released its Q4 and FY 2025 earnings, and they continue to build on an impressive series of strong growth results. For the year, revenue climbed to a record of $16.31 billion, beating estimates, up 45% on FX-neutral terms, from $11.67 billion a year prior (39% when adjusted for dollar debasement) and up almost 10-fold from 2021, with a 5-year revenue CAGR of 68%. That's mostly thanks to a CAGR of 30% in average revenue per active customer (ARPAC), reaching a record of $15 from just $5 in 2021.

Q4 shows why NU stands yet again as one of the role models of world banking efficiency. Both gross and net income continue to grow at a fast pace. A net loss of $365 million just 2 years ago in FY 2022 turned positive to an all-time high net profit of $2.9 billion in FY 2025.

The company started an impressive double-digit growth in net income in each of the last four quarters, after maintaining very thin growth in the quarters prior. This strong earnings trajectory shows me the company hit the vein in their operations and is on the right track for a sustainable level of high growth. One that is being replicated to the other markets that they are already expanding to (i.e., Mexico, Colombia).

Its disciplined, low-cost operations and operational leverage are the heart of it all. To me, this is where the magic happens. It helped turn a 3.9% net margin from Q4 2022 to more than 18.4% in Q4 2025. This shows serious operating leverage as scale builds. Being able to grow revenue per active customer while rapidly growing their customer base and still maintaining a cost per active user below the dollar level at $0,8 is no simple task.

This is highlighted by monthly ARPAC growth when analyzed long-term. It demonstrates NU's lifetime value potential and repeatability of the model. Mature cohorts, often 5-8+ years old, reach $25 to $30 monthly revenue, well above the monthly average of $15. It shows strong monetization over time as the bank earns the client's trust and more products are layered on.

Also, NU's efficiency ratio (ER) has been consistently declining, down from 78% in Q4 2021 to 20% in Q4 2025. It's basically how much of every dollar in revenue goes to running the business. To put it in perspective, Itaú's ER was 39% in Q4 2025. Clearly, being asset-light is one of Nubank's main advantages compared to traditional legacy banks. Of course, and as management anticipates, expansion into other markets can temporarily pressure margins as they are not fully matured.

NU delivered a standout ROE of 33%, way above the industry's 11.5%, stating that the digital banking business model is here to stay. Also, return on capital is 14.3% versus peers' 3.4%. This screams efficiency.

Growth Drivers and Expansion Plans

In my view, NU's 2026 outlook is bolstered by several catalysts, both globally and locally in Brazil. The first is its ongoing international expansion to Mexico and Colombia, along with its foundational steps toward a full-scale U.S. launch.

The bank is building the foundation to scale their model globally, while Latin America has the potential to repeat history in two new high-growth markets with consumer behaviors quite similar to Brazil. The core model remains about low customer acquisition costs, followed by cross-selling to build on lifetime value. The blueprint is there to follow.

In Mexico, NU plans a $4.2 billion investment to fuel expansion, where it already has 13 million customers. The unit achieved a banking charter upgrade in 2025, enabling broader services. Mexico's operations are exactly where Brazil's were at NU's beginning, yet more profitable and with a lot more share to gain (now only 14% of the population, compared to 61% in Brazil).

Its S-curve is steeper, while Brazil's seems to be reaching a flatter growth. Colombia, though smaller (4 million customers), shows similar promise to Mexico, with rapid customer adds.

Brazil's new income tax exemption could be one of the biggest tailwinds to Nubank in 2026. Last year, the Brazilian Government announced a raise of the minimum threshold in the income tax bracket for tax exemption and also discounts for mid-bracket individuals, both beginning this year.

This is estimated to leave, on average, R$3,000 more each year not paid in tax, to around 20-25 million customers that can now spend even more. That is also expected to inject R$28 billion (~US$5.4 billion) into the economy via consumer spending. This is one of many demagogic measures the government took to begin an electoral year, seeking reelection.

Now let's do some quick and conservative math: 25 million people impacted by the exemption times R$3,000 a year, that's R$75 billion of net new money per year on the table. Obviously, not all of it will go to Nubank. But it's quite fair to say that most of them are clients of NU.

Yet, not many analysts (if any!) are considering how this could impact NU's operations, given they mostly target lower-income individuals. By the government's expectations, around 41% of this total will be spent immediately, but I believe it will be much more, closer to 70%!

There are two channels where Nubank can profit from this opportunity. The first one is consumer saving. More funding through the NuConta savings account, yielding CDI (14.90% a year), while, conservatively, the bank earns a spread of 1% to 2%. Let's say only 20% of NU's active clients in Brazil are directly benefited, so around 22.6 million clients. If only 30% of the extra money stays at NuConta, at a 2% spread, that's roughly R$406 million ($79 million) a year of extra revenue for the bank.

The second channel is, well, spending. Brazilians spend almost all of their salary monthly (be it discretionary or not), especially among low-income groups. So, more money means more spending using Nubank's credit card. More credit card spending means more interchange fees (around 1%-2% per transaction). If 70% of the extra money is spent and only 40% of what is spent is done so with the credit card, this could add up to R$379 million (US$74 million) of revenue a year.

Also, the more a customer earns, the higher the credit limit tends to be - and the more credit the bank can originate. This could also boost credit volume while also reducing provisions, increasing revenue by another R$500M to R$1B a year. All added up, this could mean a total of R$1 to R$1.7 billion (up to $331 million) in extra annual revenue not priced in. I'll be closely looking for company guidance on this subject after its Q1 2026 earnings release.

Another powerful new chapter to NU's operations is its U.S. Market Entry: On January 29, 2026, NU received conditional OCC approval for a U.S. national bank charter, targeting underserved populations across all 50 states. Launch is planned for 2027, but preparations-including appointing former Brazil Central Bank President Roberto Campos Neto as chairman- are already taking place and signal serious intent.

This move tests NU's ability to replicate its LatAm success in a mature market, potentially unlocking new revenue streams, in order to evolve into a global digital banking platform.

NU also intends to secure a full banking license in Brazil in 2026, enhancing its offerings while retaining the Nubank brand. This could improve funding costs and product diversity in its core market, where it serves over half of Brazil's adult population.

On a lesser note, Partnerships and Branding with big players like Amazon, Uber, Burger King, iFood, and Shopee could also bolster NU's expansion to new customers in new locations. A recently closed multi-year deal with Mercedes-AMG PETRONAS F1 Team, starting in 2026, surely boosts global visibility and has the possibility to bring higher-net-worth customers. Good timing for marketing, considering Nubank's entrance into the U.S. market.

AI and efficiency is another hot topic. It is being adopted by the bank as a structural tool to drive better decisions, personalized experiences for clients, and stronger economics. From CEO David Velez's comments in their Q3 conference call:

Our vision is to become AI-First, which means integrating foundation models deeply into our operations to drive an AI-native interface to banking, while creating meaningful benefits for both our customers and our business.

NU's pivot to an "AI-first" bank enhances personalization, cost controls and supports profitable scaling. AI helps with credit decisions (through nuFormer credit underwriting in Brazil) to prevent fraud and minimize provisions, keeping delinquencies low, and also helps to identify product cross-sell opportunities.

Valuation

As of February 25, Nu Holdings closed at $16.67 per share, reflecting a market capitalization of approximately $80.68 billion. This positions the stock with a trailing price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio of 32.04, based on trailing twelve-month earnings per share (EPS) of $0.59. On a 1Y forward basis, the P/E drops to 19.61, incorporating analyst expectations for continued earnings growth. These multiples suggest a premium valuation relative to traditional banks (industry average trailing P/E around 12.99x), but they appear more reasonable when viewed through the lens of Nu's high-growth fintech profile.

Applying a conservative 25x multiple to 2026 EPS of $0.85 yields a target price of $21.25, implying ~26% upside from current levels. More aggressive scenarios (e.g., 30x, aligning with high-growth fintechs) could push it to $25.50.

Against Latin American peers (e.g., Itaú Unibanco or Banco Bradesco), Nu's P/E is a premium due to its digital-first model and 131 million customers (with 86% monthly engagement). Versus global fintechs like SoFi or Revolut (private), Nu's valuation is competitive, especially with net margins expanding to 18.4% in Q4 2025 from near-zero in 2022. In a neobank comparison (e.g., vs. Inter & Co.), Nu stands out for its 2026 potential due to its scale and AI pivot.

In the broader industry, U.S. banks trade at around 12x P/E, but high-growth disruptors often command 20-30x. Nu's 19.61x forward aligns it closer to the latter, yet shows me the market does not price in all of NU's potential. There's room for a strong rerating if U.S. entry (via recent OCC approval) succeeds.

Risks to Consider

Being a Brazilian myself, I'm not blind to the downsides. Brazil's economy can be volatile-elections, inflation, constant legal uncertainty -though Nu's credit quality has held up well so far. Competition is fierce from traditional local banks like Itaú, neobanks like Inter & Co., and in the U.S., it'll be JPMorgan, Chime, etc. Valuation-wise, trailing P/E is around 32x, forward around 20x premium to traditional banks, but justified by the growth. Volatility from macro or regulatory delays is always possible. Also, getting full U.S. compliance and Brazilian license approval isn't guaranteed. In my view, though, the risk of a right-wing candidate winning the election this year and changing tax brackets to what they once were seems remote.

Conclusion

Nu Holdings remains a compelling growth story. To me, NU's competing with MercadoLibre (MELI) to become Latin America's most valuable company in a few years. The valuation now, while not "cheap" in absolute terms, is undemanding relative to 30%+ growth and improving profitability. The data supports upside of 25-31%, making it attractive despite recent surges, provided execution on global expansion continues and the firm can capitalize on political, fiscal/economic tailwinds. In summary, I rate NU as a buy for long-term investors, with a fair value range of $18-22.

data.title: RLX Technology: Strategic International Expansion With Margin Upside
data.description:
Investment Thesis

RLX Technology (RLX) is focusing on expanding its international exposure through strategic investments and a franchise model. This should help the company navigate the pressures from Mainland China, where sales of illegal products are affecting the volume of compliant products. Additionally, the margins are expected to improve, supported by benefits from a favourable revenue mix and operating leverage. The company is trading at a discount of ~43% to its long-term average. Given the strategic initiatives and this discount, I believe it is an attractive investment opportunity.

Business Overview

The company is engaged in the business of Development and Sale of closed-system vaping products under the RELX brand. The company’s main source of Revenue is from the sale of Devices and pods, mainly in the regions of Mainland China and an increasing presence in European and Asian Markets in lieu of growing demand. They are operating in a highly regulated industry, with Geographic diversification and compliance with the regulations forming a key part of their strategy.

Revenue Analysis & Outlook

In the third quarter of FY2025, the company reported net sales of RMB 1,129 million in Q3 FY2025, an increase of 49% year-over-year and 28% from the previous quarter. This was driven by increased international exposure, especially strong growth in the East Asian market. Additionally, Europe contributed through the inclusion of the net sales result of the invested e-vapor business. However, the sales from Mainland China remain sluggish due to the sales of illegal substitutes.

Looking ahead in FY2026, the company should drive revenue growth from the international markets. The strategic investment in Europe and the retail franchise model in East Asia should be a tailwind in the coming quarters. However, China should remain subdued but improve in the future.

RLX Technology entered into a strategic investment agreement with a European-based e-vapor company in March 2025. This partnership aims to increase the international exposure of the company, especially related to European regulatory-compliant business. Moreover, this initiative should enable the company to tap direct access to the market by becoming a local operator rather than a remote supplier. The third quarter of FY2025 was the first quarter that the company included consolidated net sales from this strategic investment. This implies that the net sales from the partnership should help support robust growth on a year-over-year comparison through the first half of FY2026.

In East Asia, the vape market is fragmented, due to which independent vape stores dominate the category sales and impact customer purchase patterns. This market fragmentation has negatively impacted the company and increased competition from noncompliant products. With a franchise model, the company aims to provide renovation subsidies for enhancing the retail stores' experience. This initiative involves 450 partners, which should drive revenue growth in the coming quarters.

While the regulatory tailwind should support the net sales from China, the challenges in the market should continue to persist in the near term. Mainland China is actively working on strengthening the regulatory enforcement around e-vapor, which should change the market dynamics. The increased customer inspections have limited the illegal re-entry of exported products, which should make the customers switch back to regulatory-compliant products. However, the unregulated e-vapor market still poses a headwind due to online sales of these illegal products. The third quarter’s net sales from Mainland China represent ~13% of Q2 FY2021 levels, indicating the persistent challenges in the market. Therefore, I believe in continued reduced net sales from the China region. With a potential recovery if there are continued enforcement actions against illegal online sales of e-vapor products.

Margin Analysis & Outlook

The non-GAAP operating margin stood at 16.7%, an improvement of 400 basis points and 370 basis points quarter on quarter. The improvements were driven by a favorable geographic revenue mix from East Asia & Europe, consolidation of higher-margin European business, and volume leverage.

Looking ahead, I believe the margins should expand on a year-over-year comparison, driven by a favourable geographic revenue mix, particularly from the equity investment in the European business. Although regulatory enhancements in China are dynamic, I believe the increased international exposure should provide support to gross margins. Moreover, the volume leverage from revenue growth should provide support to the non-GAAP operating margin, but overall expansion depends on market stability.

In FY2026, the margins of the company should continue to benefit from the inclusion of higher-margin European business, which should lead to a favourable geographic mix. Given increasing international revenue as a % of total net sales, the overall gross margins should improve in the coming quarters. Moreover, with revenue growth, the company should benefit from the volume leverage if the fixed cost absorption is spread over a broader base, supporting the operating profit.

On the contrary, the company should continue to face challenges from the regulatory uncertainties and competitive landscape in Mainland China. The continued illegal market activity, especially online illegal product sales, should limit volume growth and pricing power. Given these conditions, I believe the performance from China should weigh on overall margin expansion in the coming quarters.

Q4 Earnings Preview

The revenue growth in the fourth quarter of FY2025 should be supported by the contribution from the strategic investment in the European e-vapor business. Given the growth in this business, the year-over-year comparison of net sales should remain favourable in the coming quarter. However, the performance in Mainland China should remain subdued due to regulatory dynamics and continued sales of illegal products.

On the margin front, the gross margin should be supported by the higher-margin European business in the fourth quarter. However, the sustainability of the margin expansion depends on competitive pressures in China, which may offset the benefits of a favourable mix on the margins.

Valuation

RLX Technology is currently trading at a P/E Non-GAAP (FWD) ratio of 17.57x with an FY2026 consensus EPS estimate of $0.14. With a growing international exposure, particularly in the European market, the growth in revenue should remain supported. Additionally, adoption of the franchise model in East Asia should also act as a tailwind for the company's revenue growth in the coming quarters. However, the market challenges in Mainland China should continue to weigh on the net sales. The company should drive margin expansion supported by a favourable geographic revenue mix and operating leverage. Given these factors, I believe the company should meet the current consensus estimate with potential upside if there is stronger regulatory enforcement on the illegal products in China.

Risk

My investment thesis is premised on the growth from the strategic investment that the company made in Europe, along with traction from its franchise model. However, if regulatory compliance requirements change or operations from international exposure do not meet expectations, it may negatively impact the company's earnings. Moreover, if regulatory enforcement fails to control the illegal products in China, it may further deteriorate the performance of the company.

Conclusion

With a P/E ratio of 17.57 and a 5-year average of 25.14x, the company is trading at a ~43% discount. While it is true that the outlook for Mainland China is likely to remain sluggish, the company is progressing toward increasing its international exposure through strategic investments in Europe. Additionally, improved brand positioning in East Asia should support earnings growth. Considering the growth drivers along with the discount based on long-term averages, I recommend a Buy rating on the stock.

data.title: CareTrust REIT: Upgraded As The Senior & Skilled Nursing Niche Keeps Bulls Charging
data.description:
As a REIT enthusiast, my pick to follow up on this week is CareTrust REIT (CTRE), which is up around +49% since my initial coverage last January calling it a buy and still continues going up since I recommended holding it back in early January, prior to the most recent earnings results.

In both cases, my confidence in this stock was driven by macro forecasts pointing to demand for senior-care property, but also the company's robust portfolio growth and expansion into the UK market.

For readers new to this stock, this California-based healthcare REIT is focused on skilled nursing, senior housing, and other healthcare-related properties located in the United States and the United Kingdom.

Notably, it recently had earnings results on Feb. 12th where it was in line with estimates, so today I did a holistic follow-up of this stock using new data points and additional angles to see if the prior thesis changes.

Thesis Summary

After my updated research this time, I'm actually upgrading this stock to a strong buy, agreeing with the most recent Wall St. consensus, and it's one of my few stocks so far in 2026 to get a perfect bullish score across the board, as my worksheet shows below:

My thesis today presents the case that the upside for CTRE could come from further demand for senior care and skilled nursing, its compelling performance vs. peers in several metrics so far, an investment-grade rating from Fitch, a convincing dividend story, and technical patterns supporting a continuing bullish view.

Continue reading to learn more about each of the 8 categories I reviewed this time, giving additional color and perspective to my prior ratings.

Macro & Sector Outlook

Let's first understand just what the market for this REIT is, and we can learn a lot from the following geomap on the Company Website:

So, what comes to mind are forecasts that could tell which direction the senior housing and skilled nursing niche could be going. For one thing, there is an aging population. Last October, the World Health Organization wrote:

By 2030, 1 in 6 people in the world will be aged 60 years or over. At this time the share of the population aged 60 years and over will increase from 1 billion in 2020 to 1.4 billion.

The pressure this puts on the senior care niche was echoed in a CNBC article this winter, which said:

The senior population is skyrocketing as baby boomers peak and nursing homes start to see more residents.

So, as in my prior articles on this stock, I believe there is a natural demand driver for these types of facilities, and although CTRE is the landlord and does not directly deal with patients, it partners with healthcare operators who do that part. For instance, Q4 results show that The Ensign Group is a major operator they work with.

At the same time, though, the demand for services in this sector has put a strain on the ability to find a qualified workforce, with even back in 2022 an article in the Natl. Library of Medicine pointing out that:

...87% of nursing homes have moderate to high levels of staffing shortages, and hiring new staff has been challenging for 98% of nursing homes.

I think that further supports the argument that demand could continue being a tailwind for this niche, and so I am highly bullish in this section.

Competitive Positioning

When it comes to competitive positioning, CTRE does not directly manage the patients, but it can compete for investors with similar REITs, so here are some metrics to consider.

First off, I picked three publicly traded REIT comparables in the senior care/skilled nursing niche: LTC Properties (LTC), Omega Healthcare Investors (OHI), and Welltower (WELL). In terms of market cap, CTRE is somewhere in the middle, with Welltower being clearly the largest.

Though not the biggest, CTRE led in top-line growth with a five-year revenue CAGR of nearly +22%, based on peer data, and it was 2nd in return on equity with an ROE of +9.1%, also impressive.

Another competitive edge could be its UK expansion. In fact, CareTrust's CEO, Dave Sedgwick, said in an interview for NAREIT last year that acquiring Care REIT plc was a:

...transformative deal, marking its first international expansion, as well as adding 135 properties and diversifying its geographic footprint and portfolio mix.

Further, we cannot ignore the fact that momentum data shows CTRE with a 10-year price return of +246%, not only beating the peer group but also edging above a major benchmark like the S&P 500, something I have not seen many REITs I've covered being able to do yet:

Given these multiple positive factors, I am highly bullish in this category too.

Company Growth Factors

Now, let's move on to company-specific growth factors.

We've already mentioned the UK expansion last year, so that is a key milestone in terms of portfolio growth.

Because REITs often do both acquiring and disposing of some property, or property "recycling" as some call it, what I look for is net portfolio growth, as that could drive future leasing income, considering leases are long-term drivers of cash flow.

In that regard, the recent Q4 and FY25 results (pg. 5) show robust net portfolio growth in the skilled nursing and senior housing niche:

In fact, in his Q4 remarks, CEO Sedgwick said:

We have a bigger, more diverse, and stronger portfolio today than this time last year.

Complementing this growth thesis is Seeking Alpha data showing expected forward revenue growth at +29%, easily beating the sector average.

Thus, this company growth picture only further supports my already highly bullish view so far in this article and should add confidence to future-minded investors considering where this REIT may be heading, and it does not seem to be a contraction but a direction of expansion.

Profitability Metrics

In this section, let's focus on some figures that could impact profitability.

Before discussing margins, since this is a REIT, it is worth mentioning its AFFO growth since that impacts dividend coverage, and notable from Seeking Alpha data is a five-year AFFO CAGR of +4.2%, beating the sector average.

The margin I would focus on is the EBITDA margin, since it takes out the noise that property depreciation can create, so here is how CTRE compares with peers:

What gets attention is CTRE's EBITDA margin of nearly +85%, which is nearly the best in this peer group, but also you can see the trend line rising over the last year, a positive direction showing margin improvement.

Notable also is that CTRE has a considerable amount of "triple net lease" properties, thus lowering its operating costs on those properties since many costs in that model are passed to the tenant/operator.

Additionally, I would point out from Q4 results (pg 3) the company had positive earnings guidance for FY26, saying:

The midpoints of our Normalized FFO and Normalized FAD guidance represent increases of 9.4% and 9.4%, respectively, over 2025 results.

I also want to point out some more granular data from the income statement, where we can see steady growth in rental revenue in recent years, yet the property expenses have not really grown, so this is an interesting trend to consider that bolsters the argument supporting the triple-net-lease model:

Beyond my own view, let's also consider the analyst consensus, which shows expected YoY FFO growth of between 10% and 13% this year and next, so this also supports the case for potential for further upside.

Given the above points made, which include a strong EBITDA margin among peers, a proven AFFO growth over five years, positive company guidance for FY26, a lower-cost triple net lease model, and the positive analyst FFO consensus, I am a strong buy in this section as well, and so far this stock has a perfect "5" score from me.

However, let's see if the balance sheet risk profile changes that, so keep reading on.

Balance Sheet Risk

In this section, I think it is worth considering credit ratings, D/E ratio, and tenant risk exposure in the asset portfolio.

Notable to mention here is that Fitch gave this firm an investment grade of BBB- last year, and it is worth noting it pointed out that:

CTRE's credit profile further benefits from its limited near-term maturities and fully unencumbered portfolio.

In terms of D/E ratio, from the latest data since my last rating, here is how CTRE stands among peers:

In this comparison, CTRE has the lowest D/E at just 0.22, and if you notice the trend line, it has actually come down, which is a great sign, indicating lower reliance on leverage.

Third, considering this REIT has a huge property portfolio, asset risk can come from tenant over-concentration or geographic concentration, something I've not only said in many REIT articles but also in my new book on REITs, and so I'll mention it here too.

From the Q4 financial supplement (pg. 8), I am looking for exposure to population growth states in the south/southeast US, and in that regard, this REIT has grown in Texas, Tennessee, and Louisiana, which I think mitigates over-concentration in its home state of California. Also, the UK exposure diversifies the portfolio beyond just the US:

In terms of tenants/operators, where my bullishness pulls back somewhat is the fact that nearly 1/4th of rent is being driven by The Ensign Group, so I think the risk needle moves up somewhat because of this.

Because of that, I am not highly bullish in this section but simply just bullish, since the strong credit rating and very low D/E are very strong points to consider.

Dividend Outlook

Next, let's talk about dividends, such as yield, growth, and sustainability, to keep it holistic.

The yield of 3.3% is nothing remarkable and is actually below the sector average, so it does not fall into my pool of high-yield REITs.

The REIT does have a proven case for steady dividend growth, though, with a 10-year dividend CAGR of +7.6%, clearly beating the sector average and showing it can be resilient through many economic cycles and market shocks (pandemic, inflation, high interest rates, etc.).

In fact, as a dividend investor myself in REITs, the following dividend growth trend is just what I look for:

As far as sustainability, in Q4 results (pg. 3), the company said:

During the fourth quarter, CareTrust declared a quarterly dividend of $0.335 per common share. On an annualized basis, the payout ratio was approximately 71% based on fourth quarter 2025 Normalized FFO.

At below 75%, I believe the payout ratio is still reasonable and not getting into dangerous territory, so it would appear they can cover the dividend adequately, and the FFO growth projections and strong margins should continue to support the case for dividend safety going forward.

Also, think about the fact that this type of REIT is not subject to the same cyclical swings that a hotel REIT or retail REIT could be, which are exposed to consumer spending confidence, seasonal travel and shopping trends, and recessionary factors. It doesn't make those REIT sectors bad, since I invest in them actually, but it just presents a very different risk profile to consider.

So, I am bullish on CTRE's dividend story and am including it in my dividend ideas for February.

Valuation Metrics

To change things up, here I'll present my valuation and price target worksheet, which I did not include in my initial rating of this stock, yet I think could add some more color to the thesis. The worksheet uses Seeking Alpha data on valuation and FFO estimates and uses the fwd P/FFO and FFO estimate to determine a price target.

We have a case of an undervalued stock that also shows potential upside of +10%. My upside forecast is actually close to the avg. Wall St. target of +7.2% upside.

At the same time, I've already shown that CTRE has strong and improving margins, a positive earnings guidance for the near term, and beats several peers on ROE, so I would call this an undervaluation opportunity with upside potential, and hence a buy.

Technical Charting

Another new feature since my initial rating on this stock, to add an additional angle this time, is to consider technical chart patterns, with the goal of pattern recognition in price movements.

The patterns that immediately stick out are the buy signal (golden cross pattern) that formed this summer, after which both moving averages, the 50-day and 200-day SMA, have been parallel and trending upward. In addition, the share price has mostly remained above the 50-day, which is acting as a strong support so far. In fact, that support was tested, it seems, a few times, and the price just came back up again.

I am inclined to say buy based on this pattern since it seems like continuing bullish momentum rather than trend consolidation, and certainly no bearish signals are in sight.

Interestingly, this technical pattern actually supports and bolsters the rest of my article, which is based on fundamentals rather than technicals, and strengthens the overall bullish thesis even more.

Risks and Challenges to Thesis

One factor that could challenge my strong buy rating that has not been otherwise covered in this article is payor risk.

Although this applies more to this REIT's tenant operators since they are the ones getting reimbursed, it certainly can impact the REIT if its major tenants are under pressure to accept lower rates from insurers and Medicare/Medicaid, thereby impacting their own cash flow. Experienced investors and analysts in this niche, I think, are equally paying attention to this REIT's tenants, like Ensign and others, as they are to the REIT, so payor reimbursement trends come into play, and when it comes to Medicare/Medicaid, those are also subject to political decisions at the state and federal level.

It is more of a sector risk than one limited to this REIT, since all of its peers could be in the same boat, so it is important for sector investors to bake that into their risk management strategy. There is also not much of a mitigating factor here since this niche is literally fully exposed to tenants with such payor risk, unlike REITs that have stores, apartments, or data centers, for instance.

Conclusion

To wrap things up, in my follow-up on CTRE this time, I am actually upgrading it from my last few articles after considering new data and additional angles, and this time I'm agreeing with Wall St.'s strong buy consensus (as of Wednesday).

To summarize, CTRE is a compelling dividend idea that is also convincing as a growth story and offers the opportunity for portfolio exposure to the niche of healthcare REITs focused on a high-demand segment: skilled nursing and senior care, which shows plenty of reason for further upside potential.

data.title: Funko: Buying The Pipes, Not The Pops?
data.description:
Pleasant Lake Partners makes a stake

Funko Inc. (FNKO) has a new activist investor. I've covered Funko in the past. The company has been through the wringer and has been out of favor with investors for some time. Here are the details of the new activist stake.

From Reuters:

Feb 20 (Reuters) - Pleasant Lake Partners disclosed a roughly 10% stake in toymaker Funko and said the company should consider strategic alternatives, including the possibility of a sale, according to a regulatory filing from Thursday.

Shares of Funko were up about 25% on Friday. The company had a market capitalization of about $245 million as of Thursday's close.

The New York-based hedge fund said it will engage with Funko's board and management on ways to boost shareholder value, advocating for an immediate and thorough exploration of alternatives for both strategic and financial acquirers.

This company has been writing off a lot of assets, creating a negative GAAP income situation for quite some time. While non-GAAP measures remain positive, the business is seeing a top-line shrinkage:

A shrinking top-line means shrinking demand for the products they sell. Usually not a great premise for exploring a sale unless the prices were fire sale territory for the enterprise value versus the EBITDA.

What they do

From the most recent 10K:

We create products to attract a broad array of fans across consumer demographic groups. We believe our broad appeal comes from our large selection of licenses and properties that we apply across a variety of product categories and brands. We do not limit ourselves by targeting discrete demographics such as only collectors or children seeking the latest (and often short-lived) toy craze. We strive to have something for everyone by offering figures and other product categories including bags, wallets, apparel, plush, accessories, homewares and more. We expect to continue to look for ways to diversify our product offerings to reach an even broader group of consumers.

In addition to offering multiple properties and product categories, we create and sell a variety of unique brands that have their own look and feel. Our brand portfolio includes Core Collectible (which include Pop! Vinyl, as well as other branded lines such as Soda, Bitty Pop!, and Pop! Yourself), Loungefly (softlines including bags, wallets, backpacks and apparel)

The main products are the Funko Pop plastic toys that are in the collectible toy category, along with things like Star Wars figures, Pokémon, and Pop Mart toys. They also have a wide array of Loungefly higher-end backpacks and apparel. The IP leasing catalog is vast. If the rights to use those alone could be carried over to a buyer, that could be valuable in and of itself. The market reaction to the news of an activist stepping in was a big pop and then a subsiding. The stock is still up significantly for this short period.

Enterprise value

The company's enterprise value saw a significant rise during the Covid era as collectibles and alternative investments came back in style for a brief moment. The EV has since returned to its 2020 levels.

From a sales perspective, the company is extremely attractive, trading at less than 0.3x earnings. Anytime a price-to-sales ratio gets that low, margins are certainly an issue, as are places to reinvest to try to grow top and bottom lines.

As we can see, the toy maker's gross margins are quite attractive, but it breaks down at the operating level. Selling and administrative costs are the main sore thumb if we take a closer look:

SG&A expense has nearly doubled since 2020 as has the "other" operating expenses category. This is a company in need of better management and probably a new line of products.

The company is not extremely cheap on a price-to-book basis at 1.53X, but that might be where the actual value is.

In a private sale, looking at normalized EBITDA, this is a company that back in 2018 was able to generate 100 million in EBITDA. Trading at a $552 million enterprise value, getting back to those EBITDA rates of the past would mean the company would only be trading for about 5x EBITDA.

The balance sheet is not horrible, either, from the outside looking in. Current annual net debt to EBITDA is sitting at 1.82 X after backing cash out of the LT debt number.

The toy shift, Labubus, clip-on plushies, and blind boxes

Being a parent of a young child, I see the shifts in toy trends. Right now, the hottest thing around is blind boxes that contain various clip-on plushies that kids can dangle off their backpacks. Being that each open is a mystery [sealed in a bag], this combines the attractiveness of something like a Funko Pop toy with the mystery of a Pokémon pack rip.

For those that haven't seen them, this is the most popular variety called "Labubus". The Popmart stores and brands are headquartered in Beijing, China, and the company is listed in Hong Kong. Many of the artists and creators of the themes are from China.

Popmart stores are now all over the US and the world.

Popmarts are now "popping up" all over the world, and the world has a wide reach.

Why all the fuss about Popmart

This is because I believe the size and type of vinyl that Funko Pops use is pretty similar to what you'll find on Popmart blind box toys, minus the fur. This could be a capacity sale combined with a licensing agreement acquisition story.

Although Funko designs the toys in the US, they are manufactured in China, Vietnam, and Mexico, so we can assume that China-based Popmart would be familiar with the company's manufacturing and logistics operations already.

Another competitor that may want the capacity could also be Miniso (MNSO). This Guangzhou, China based company is listed in the US and has a replica business model to Popmart. Toy stores all over the US and abroad are stocked with Asian-themed blind box toys and accessories.

Summary

An activist investor buying a stake and publicly promoting a sale exploration tells me they could see the assets, licensing, and logistics as key marketing components. The existing pop toys and backpacks are not gaining any further market share and falling out of style, it appears. My analysis is that the manufacturing assets are the key value proposition for more popular toy brands to acquire.

data.title: TJX Companies Q4 Results: Operating Strength Continues, Shares Fairly Valued
data.description:
Off-price retailer, TJX Companies (TJX), continues to impress investors with better-than-expected results and strong momentum in the current economic environment, which clearly favors those with off-price appeal.

I have provided continuing coverage in TJX in prior periods, and it has been one name that I have expressed bullishness early on in its growth cycle.

When I first covered TJX in early 2022, I noted that investors were missing an opportunity in TJX, given its discount appeal in an era of strong inflationary pressures. I then provided six more ‘buy’ calls before finally turning more neutral in early 2024.

Shares in TJX have gained over 150% since my first update, and that compares to the 50% gain in the broader S&P (SPY) over the same period.

Today, with shares trading near the top-end of its 52-week range and at levels which appear priced to perfection, I remain neutral and view the name as a ‘sideline’ stock worth watching until a better entry point inevitably arrives.

TJX Stock Key Metrics

At the time of my early coverage in TJX, overall sentiment among the broader Seeking Alpha (“SA”) community and associated quants was similarly bullish. Sentiment since then has gradually become more neutral. This seems natural, given the steady rise in the stock’s trading multiple.

At current prices, TJX commands a forward trading multiple of over 30x earnings. This compares to its historical averages in the mid-20x range. I believe the premium is justified, especially given TJX’s ongoing appeal in the current high-priced consumer environment, as well as its strong operating results.

While the SA community is broadly neutral on TJX, analysts on Wall Street are seeing additional upside remaining. Granted, the potential is less than 10% from current trading levels based on the current price target. I believe that TJX can certainly reach this target, but it’s not exactly an impressive rate of return, in my view.

TJX Q4 Results Recap

TJX closed out the year exactly the way investors have come to expect, and that is by outperforming.

The Q4 topline rose 9%, while consolidated comp sales increased a very strong 5%, ahead of plan and on top of a 5% increase last year. That’s a tough comparison made to look easy, in my view.

Importantly, the comp was driven by both higher average ticket and increased transactions, a clear sign that traffic remains healthy and consumers are responding to the value proposition.

Profitability was just as impressive, in my view. Adjusted gross margin expanded 60 basis points to 31.1%, helped by stronger merchandise margins and expense leverage.

Pretax margin improved to 12.2%, also up 60 basis points, and adjusted EPS came in at $1.43, up 16% YOY and $0.05/share ahead of expectations. Shrink improvement was another highlight, with management noting levels are now essentially back to pre-COVID norms.

Full-year results justify TJX’s current stock outperformance, in my view. Total sales, for example, surpassed the +$60B mark and EPS climbed 11% YOY. In addition, every division posted comp growth of 4% or better.

What Is The Outlook For TJX Stock?

Looking ahead, the guidance remains positive with a hint of a ‘back to earth’ vibe as it relates to the growth trajectory.

Drilling down into it, for FY27, TJX is calling for comp sales growth of 2% to 3%, a step down from the 5% pace delivered this year. In addition, total sales are expected to rise 4% to 5%, with EPS projected between $4.93 and $5.02, representing growth of 4% to 6%.

Margins are also expected to remain healthy. Gross margin is guided to improve modestly to 31.1%–31.2%, driven by higher merchandise margins, while pretax margin is expected to be flat to up slightly.

What’s important for TJX is that they continue to invest in growth, and it appears they will be meeting that expectation in the new fiscal year. The company plans to open 146 net new stores, complete more than 500 remodels, and spend over +$2B in CAPEX to support long-term expansion.

At the same time, shareholders will continue to benefit from meaningful capital returns, including a planned 13% dividend increase and up to +$2.8B in buybacks.

Is TJX Stock A Buy, Sell, Or Hold?

There’s no question in my mind that TJX remains one of the best bets in retail. I actually had titled one of my past articles this tag in early 2023.

Backing up this statement today is that traffic trends remain healthy, margins are expanding, and management is confidently investing in long-term growth. This is exactly what you want to see from a best-in-class off-price retailer, in my view.

That said, shares have run up in a significant way since my early calls on the stock.

With shares trading at over 30x forward earnings and sitting near the top end of the 52-week range, I believe much of the operational strength is already reflected in the stock.

The guidance for FY27 calls for solid, but more normalized, mid-single-digit earnings growth. That type of growth profile simply does not leave a wide margin of safety at current valuation levels, in my view.

Could shares grind higher? Absolutely. The management team has earned the benefit of the doubt from me on that. But with consensus price targets implying less than 10% upside and the multiple well above historical norms, I don’t see a compelling risk-reward setup here.

For long-term holders who are likely sitting on hefty gains, I believe TJX remains a core, high-quality name worth owning. For new investment, however, patience may be rewarded. At current levels, I view TJX as a ‘hold’, waiting for a more attractive entry point.

data.title: BJ's Restaurants Keeps Getting Tastier
data.description:
After the market closed on February 25th, the management team at BJ's Restaurants (BJRI) announced financial results for the final quarter of the company's 2025 fiscal year. Surprisingly, revenue and adjusted earnings per share both came in above what analysts anticipated. What's more, management is forecasting further growth in 2026 to take financial performance higher than what the business has seen over the last couple of years now.

Conceptually, this is great. And what's even better is that, on both an absolute basis and relative to other similar firms, the stock is priced at levels that look cheap. Naturally, this would draw my attention. In the past, however, the market has not really agreed with me all that much. In fact, back in May of 2025, I ended up upgrading the stock from a ‘hold’ to a ‘buy’. Since then, however, the stock has risen only 9.1%, falling woefully short of the 22.8% increase that the S&P 500 has achieved. But honestly, considering how cheap the stock is and factoring in its continued growth, I firmly stand by my previous assessment.

A great way to end 2025

The final quarter of the 2025 fiscal year was, in many respects, a positive time for shareholders of BJ's Restaurants. Management reported revenue for the quarter of $355.4 million. That happened to be an increase of 3.2% over the $344.3 million the company reported a year earlier, and it exceeded analysts' estimates by $1.6 million. Some of this rise was driven by an increase in the number of locations in operation from 218 to 219. But that's not the only thing that added to the top line growth. The company also reported comparable restaurant sales growth of 2.6%, pushing overall comparable sales up to 2% for 2025 in its entirety compared to the 1.2% achieved from 2024 to 2025.

According to management, traffic growth was particularly robust, jumping 4.5% year over year. This was fueled by continued innovation when it comes to the company's menu. For instance, during the quarter, it built on its seasonal Pizookie momentum, specifically through the return of its Monkey Bread Pizookie and the introduction of its Dubai Chocolate Pizookie. The latter of these also entitled patrons to an accompanying martini. The firm also launched its renovated pizza platform that management said is currently resonating well with guests and achieving consistent performance. This does not mean that management is focused only on expanding its menu. In fact, the company ended 2025 with a net reduction of six menu items and four ingredient SKUs. Plus, it is investing more into not only its social media presence, specifically through relevant product news, but also it is relying on word of mouth. The fact that the company completed 19 remodels throughout 2025, bringing the total number of remodels systemwide to just shy of 50%, means that customers are having a new experience that is certainly bringing them back time and time again. These changes have included certain technological improvements as well, such as tagging and tracking its equipment. The goal here is to remain more operationally efficient, and as you will see shortly, that is certainly having a positive impact on the bottom line.

Speaking of profits, earnings per share for the quarter came in at $0.58. While that represented a meaningful improvement over the $0.23 in losses that the company incurred the previous year, it did, unfortunately, fall short of expectations that analysts had set to the tune of $0.03. But still, the fact that the company went from a net loss of $5.3 million to a net profit of $12.6 million is most certainly something to write home about. Adjusted earnings per share did considerably better, rising from $0.47 to $0.66. In addition to exceeding analysts’ estimates by $0.04, the improvement meant a rise in adjusted net income from $11.1 million to $14.3 million. I wish I could say that we had data regarding operating cash flow. But at this time, we don't. We do know, however, that on a year-over-year basis, EBITDA for the company expanded from $33.1 million to $35.6 million.

In the chart above, you can see financial results for 2025 in their entirety compared to 2024. Revenue, earnings, and adjusted earnings all increased nicely. Also on the rise ended up being EBITDA. What's really awesome is that management expects continued momentum into 2026. Management continues to focus on building engagement with its seasonal Pizookies. Plus, it is likely to continue rolling out innovative products. That's not just speculation. In fact, management specified in their latest earnings call that they are in the early stages of testing refreshes to their burger category and chicken sandwiches. The goal of all of this is to build on the foundations of the company laid in 2025. And if that goes according to plan, overall comparable sales for 2026 should rise by another 1% to 3%.

From that, we should expect EBITDA of somewhere between $140 million and $150 million for the year. That compares nicely to the $134.1 million the company reported for 2025. In all likelihood, this would mean a rise in adjusted net profits from $51.1 million to $55.3 million. And it should mean growth in adjusted operating cash flow to around $179.3 million. As I mentioned earlier in this article, management has not provided comprehensive cash flow data yet. But this growth was based on projecting out results for the first nine months of 2025 compared to the same time in 2024. That would have meant a rise in adjusted operating cash flow from $141.9 million in 2024 to $165.8 million last year.

Using these estimates, we can see in the chart above how shares of the company are priced at the moment. Honestly, these are very low multiples. This is especially true when it comes to the cash flow figures. Relative to other similar restaurant companies, the stock is certainly trading on the cheaper end of the spectrum as well. In that same chart, you can see how it compares to five other similar terms. On a price-to-earnings basis, only two of the five companies are cheaper than it is. One of them is cheaper on a price to operating cash flow basis. Meanwhile, when it came to the EV to EBITDA approach, BJ's Restaurants ended up being cheaper than any of these companies.

Takeaway

Based on all the data provided right now, I must say that I am feeling very optimistic about BJ's Restaurants. Management has done an exceptional job as of late. For some reason, the market is still resistant to this candidate. The firm has increased since I last wrote about it. But it has not increased anywhere near enough to justify anything other than a bullish outlook. Given this, I believe that maintaining BJ's Restaurants as a very solid ‘buy’ candidate is the right move.

data.title: Harbor Mid Cap Value Fund Q4 2025 Commentary
data.description:
"While technology-related stocks saw the largest gains, other sectors of the market also benefited from the broadening of the market advance." - LSV Asset Management

Market in Review

U.S. equities delivered positive gains in the fourth quarter of 2025, consolidating a strong year. The S&P 500 Index increased 2.7% during the quarter, bringing full-year returns to 17.9%. Performance was shaped by the evolving monetary policy backdrop following the Federal Reserve's ("Fed") initial rate cut in September, with additional cuts in October and December, as investors balanced expectations for a gradual easing cycle against evidence of slowing, but still resilient economic fundamentals. The Fed maintained its data-dependent messaging throughout the quarter, signaling willingness to ease further as inflation continued moderating toward its target while labor market conditions softened at the margin. This approach helped contain interest rate volatility and provided support for equity valuations.

Corporate earnings remained broadly positive despite moderating growth rates. Forward guidance pointed to continued, albeit more measured, profit expansion into 2026. AI and technology-related sectors continued to drive earnings leadership, though contributions broadened to include Health Care, Industrials, and Consumer Discretionary stocks.

Mid-cap stocks lagged both large- and small-cap stocks. The Russell 1000® Index was up 2.4%, and the Russell 2000® returned 2.2%, while the Russell Midcap® Index was up just 0.2%. Value stocks – as measured by the Russell Indexes – outperformed growth stocks.

Nine of the 11 S&P 500 sectors posted positive returns in the fourth quarter. Sector leadership was concentrated in the Health Care and Communication Services sectors, while Real Estate and Utilities lagged.

Portfolio Performance

During the fourth quarter, the Harbor Mid Cap Value Fund (Institutional Class, "Fund") returned 4.07%, outperforming its benchmark, the Russell Midcap® Value Index, which returned 1.42%. Among mid-caps, value stocks outperformed growth stocks, as the Russell Midcap® Growth Index returned -3.7%. The outperformance of value stocks had a positive impact on relative results given our value discipline.

We take limited sector and industry bets and look to add value primarily from bottom-up stock selection. During the fourth quarter, stock selection accounted for most of the value added, however, sector selection was also positive. From a sector perspective, the Fund's underweight to Utilities and Real Estate added value. Stock selection added value in several sectors, particularly Industrials, Consumer Discretionary, and Financials.

Contributors & Detractors

Following strong performance in the third quarter, Information Technology holding Sandisk (SNDK) significantly outperformed again in the fourth quarter. AI-driven demand for storage led to strong earnings and increases in revenue growth and margins. We trimmed our position in Sandisk given the run-up in the stock.

Other top-performing holdings were in the Consumer Discretionary sector – General Motors (GM) and Expedia (EXPE). General Motors performed well after posting strong full-year results driven by record truck sales. The company continues to return capital to investors through stock buybacks and dividend increases. Expedia, which was a recent purchase, also posted strong results and raised the outlook going forward. We added to our exposure to Expedia and continue to hold both stocks in the Fund.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ), in the Health Care sector, was a top performer, advancing nearly 30% driven by strong third quarter performance and positive clinical trial results for one of its cancer drugs. We continue to hold the company in the Fund.

Other top contributors included underweights to momentum-based stocks that are in the benchmark, Robinhood Markets (HOOD) and Coinbase Global (COIN).

While several Fund holdings struggled – including NewMarket (NEU) in the Materials sector, HP (HPQ) in the Information Technology sector, and Harley-Davidson (HOG) and PulteGroup (PHM) in the Consumer Discretionary sector – the most significant detractor was our underweight to Warner Bros. Discovery (WBD), which is in the benchmark and was up nearly 50% on acquisition activity. NewMarket struggled with general weakness in the petroleum additives business, one of the larger portions of its revenue. We continue to hold the stock in the Fund. Harley-Davidson struggled after reporting sharp declines in motorcycle revenue, increased costs, and pricing pressure. We continue to hold Harley-Davidson in the Fund. PulteGroup, in the homebuilding industry, struggled due to slowing orders and margin pressures despite a slight decrease in mortgage rates. We continue to hold PulteGroup in the Fund. HP has not benefited much from the AI frenzy like other technology companies. The company has seen rising costs and projected lower-than-expected earnings for 2026. We did not make any changes to our position in HP and continue to hold the stock in the Fund.

Buys & Sells

We initiated a position in Garrett Motion (GTX), an automotive parts and equipment company in the Consumer Discretionary sector. The company designs, manufactures, and sells turbocharger and electric boosting technologies for commercial vehicles. Garrett ranks high on multiple cash flow and forecast earnings measures on our model. The company typically pays a dividend and has been aggressively buying back stock, which we view positively. Price momentum during the past 12 months has been strong as has operating momentum, placing its momentum scores near the top decile. Overall, the stock ranks in the top 5% in our stock-ranking universe, which led to the fourth quarter purchase.

We also initiated a position in EnerSys (ENS) in the Industrials sector. EnerSys designs, manufactures, and distributes energy systems and batteries to customers worldwide. The stock ranks high on multiple cash flow and forecast earnings measure — our two most important blocks of valuation. The company typically pays a dividend and has been aggressively buying back stock, which we view positively. Price momentum over the past 12 months has been strong. In addition, several indicators of operating momentum are also attractive, with improving operating margins and growth in sales. Overall, the stock ranks in the top 5% in our stock-ranking universe, which led to the fourth quarter purchase.

We sold our position in Electronic Arts (EA) in the Communication Services sector. Electronic Arts did well in 2025, advancing approximately 40% for the year. In late September, the company announced an agreement to be acquired by Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund, Silver Lake (SVLKF), and Affinity Partners for $55 billion. The Fund often benefits from takeovers, as the companies we hold tend to be attractively priced, solid businesses that are undervalued, as was the case with Electronic Arts.

We trimmed our position in Amkor Technology (AMKR) in the Information Technology sector. Amkor has done well in recent years, benefiting from the surging demand in AI and as a result has become less attractive from a valuation standpoint. While the stock still generates good cash flow, both earnings and cash flow have not kept up with the increase in stock price. Stock price momentum has been very strong but the decline in fundamentals (valuation) led us to sell the position.

Sector Underweights and Overweights

The Fund's sector exposures are driven by valuations, as we will overweight those sectors where we find the most attractive stocks from a valuation standpoint and underweight those sectors and industries where we have difficulty finding cheap stocks.

The Fund's most significant overweights relative to the value benchmark are to the Consumer Discretionary and Financials sectors. Within the Consumer Discretionary sector, the Fund is overweight homebuilders, automotive parts, automotive retail, and broadline retail. Among Financials, the Fund is overweight consumer finance, commercial & residential mortgage finance, asset management & custody banks, regional banks, and property & casualty insurance. The most significant underweights relative to the value benchmark are to Industrials, Materials, Utilities, and Real Estate.

Outlook

U.S. equity markets finished the year strong; however, mid-cap stocks were only slightly positive in the fourth quarter and up just over 10% for the year compared to nearly 18% for the S&P 500 Index. Markets in 2025 were led by almost anything AI-related, driving up valuations for chipmakers and software firms building AI platforms. While technology-related stocks saw the largest gains, other sectors of the market also benefited from the broadening of the market advance.

Even though AI-related technology stocks may appear priced to perfection, we continue to identify opportunities among mid- and smaller-capitalization value stocks. The Fund has outperformed the value benchmark in four of the past five years, with the only exception being 2024, when the Fund matched the return of the value benchmark. Even with strong relative performance, the Fund remains attractively priced relative to the benchmark. The Fund seeks to hold high-quality, profitable companies that generate cash, pay dividends, and repurchase shares. While large-cap U.S. stocks appear quite expensive, the mid- and small-cap segments of the market continue to trade at attractive multiples, particularly value-oriented stocks. We remain committed to our disciplined value investment approach and are excited about the opportunities available to investors among mid- and small-cap value stocks.

All holdings-related data is provided by FactSet. Because FactSet relies on external sources for its data, that data may differ slightly from actual values maintained by Harbor Funds.

Due to the security valuation procedures of the Fund and intra-day trading activity not included in the FactSet calculations, the actual returns may vary. From time to time the cash return in the portfolio may appear distorted based on the way FactSet's attribution calculation methodology addresses delayed settlements.

Best and Worst Performers sections reflect stocks in the portfolio for the quarter with an average weight of 0.25% or greater.

Views expressed herein are drawn from commentary provided to Harbor by the subadvisor and may not be reflective of their current opinions or future actions, are subject to change without prior notice, and should not be considered investment advice.

This information should not be considered as a recommendation to purchase or sell a particular security. The weightings, holdings, industries, sectors, countries, and returns mentioned may change at any time and may not represent current or future investments.

As a result of changing market conditions, expenses and other statistics may change at any time and may differ from those shown.

Sector allocations are determined using the Global Industry Classification Standard (GICS), which is a service of Morgan Stanley Capital International (MSCI) and Standard & Poor's (S&P).

Investors should carefully consider the investment objectives, risks, charges and expenses of a fund before investing. To obtain a summary prospectus or prospectus for this and other information, visit Active ETFs or call 800-422-1050. Read it carefully before investing.

Distributed by Harbor Funds Distributors, Inc.

Attribution Disclosures

Attribution results are calculated by Harbor Capital based on fund holdings data obtained from State Street Bank and Trust Company and return data sourced from MSCI Inc. Where MSCI return data is unavailable, FactSet data is used as a substitute. Benchmark holdings are sourced from the respective index provider. Attribution results are based on end-of-day portfolio positions and calculated gross of any fees and expenses.

Active Currency Contribution is the Currency Contribution of the portfolio minus the Currency Contribution of the benchmark.

Allocation Effect is the portion of portfolio excess return that is attributable to taking different group bets from the benchmark. (If either the portfolio or the benchmark has no position in a given group, allocation effect is the lone effect.) A group's allocation effect equals the average percent capitalization of the portfolio's group minus the average percent cap of the benchmark's group times the total return of the benchmark group minus the total return of the benchmark.

Average Weight is the dollar value (price times the shares held) of the security or group, divided by the total dollar value of the entire portfolio displayed as a percentage. It is calculated as the simple arithmetic average of daily values.

Contribution to Return is the contribution of a security or group to the overall portfolio return. It is calculated as the security weight multiplied by the daily security return linked daily across the reporting period.

Currency Contribution is Total Return in USD subtracting out the Local Returns.

Local Returns are the Total Return of the portfolio or benchmark using the local currency.

Selection Effect is the portion of portfolio excess return attributable to choosing different securities within groups from the benchmark. A group's security selection effect equals the average weight of the benchmark's group times the total return of the portfolio's group minus the total return of the benchmark's group.

Total Effect is the sum of Allocation Effect and Selection Effect. The total effect represents the opportunity cost of what was done in a group relative to the overall portfolio. It is not just the difference between percent contribution in the portfolio and benchmark. At the overall portfolio level, the two numbers are equal. At the group level, they can be different.

Total Return is the price change of a security or group including dividends accrued over the report period (or the in-portfolio return) which includes only the time period that each security was in the portfolio.

Original Post

Editor's Note: The summary bullets for this article were chosen by Seeking Alpha editors.

data.title: Hut 8 Focuses On AI Infrastructure Growth, But Operating Profitability Is Still A Work In Progress
data.description:
I last covered Hut 8 (HUT) in November, and downgraded my rating on the company to a hold, citing their lack of operating profitability as they try to restructure the company into an energy optimization and infrastructure provider out of what was once a fairly straightforward Bitcoin mining venture.

The problems were two-fold, that the increase in share price was commanding a substantial premium to the value of the underlying Bitcoins, and that because the infrastructure business isn’t yet at break-even, that Bitcoin asset is really the only meaningful thing they own right now at a scale which means anything to shareholders.

Now we’re another quarter deep, and we’ve got the final numbers for the year. This is a good opportunity to see where the business itself stands, but also importantly a chance to reexamine the Bitcoin side of things, because the price of Bitcoins in February of 2026 isn’t what it was even a few short months ago.

Growth Is Meaningful, But Bitcoin Losses Are the Story in Q4

After positive quarters in which Hut 8’s profits were more or less entirely a function of their digital assets (which is to say, Bitcoin) appreciating in value, Q4 saw them not just turn to loss, but decidedly so. Once again, the bottom line is driven overwhelmingly by what the price of Bitcoin did, going down in this case.

Q4 2024

Q4 2025

Total Revenue

$31.7 million

$88.5 million

Gross Profit

$53.5 million

Gain on Digital Assets

$308 million

($402 million)

Operating Income

$282 million

($435 million)

Net Income

$152 million

($280 million)

Adjusted EBITDA

$311 million

($348 million)

GAAP EPS

$1.37

($2.53)

(source: press release from Q4 earnings)

Top line growth is meaningful year over year here, of course, but once again the Gain on Digital Assets line dwarfs everything else, and by the time we get to net income we’re left with either positive earnings that are exclusively from that gain, as in 2024, or a net loss that is the loss on digital assets compounded with further operating losses from the rest of the business.

One could argue, indeed, that the earnings we were seeing in past quarters are largely illusory, because the gains are entirely on paper in estimations of what digital assets are worth, and since the company never seems willing to divest those assets when they appreciate, they’re just gains until we get a quarter like this past one, where the price drops and suddenly they’re booking a loss.

Which isn’t to say that the Bitcoin holdings are worthless. As Hut 8 moves to redefine itself away from its crypto business they managed to bring in some positive cash flow from the creation of the American Bitcoin stock. But such gains are not something we can expect them to be able to repeat, nor are they something to judge the overall business around.

Cash Flow and the Margins of the Business

Putting aside the Bitcoin question for a minute, we should look at a breakdown of the revenue by different segments of the company. The conference call comment was quite accurate declaring that Compute is the company’s “real growth engine” of the company’s business, and indeed, as it grows the margin of that segment has remained the strongest.

Revenue

Cost

Margin

Power

$5.0 million

$5.4 million

(8.0%)

Digital Infrastructure

$1.6 million

Compute
